section.title: Converting DocBook from Version 4 to Version 5
Problem
section.para: You have a DocBook document in version 4.x, but you need 5.x.

section.title: Solution
section.para: Generally, the difference between version 4 and version 5 is minimal. Refer to the The Definitive Guide for detailed information what has been added, removed, or renamed.

One major change is that all DocBook 5.x elements are in the namespace http://docbook.org/ns/docbook. All these changes are taken into account by the db4-upgrade.xsl stylesheet in the DocBook Subversion repository. The URL is . You just need to apply this stylesheet to your source DocBook document, for example:

section.title: Discussion
section.para: One disadvantage is that entities are not preserved. This is not a stylesheet issue as the entities are already resolved when the XSLT processor gets its hand on the source tree. The stylesheet never sees the entities.

step.para: Open your existing document using your favorite editing tool. You must use a tool that is not XML-aware, or one that allows you to edit markup in the raw.

Replace all occurrences of the entity references that you want to preserve with some unique string. For example, if you want to preserve Product references, you could replace them all with [[[Product]]] (assuming that the string [[[Product]]] doesn't occur anywhere else in your document).
Copy the document type declaration of your document and save it some place. The document type declaration is everything from “<!DOCTYPE” to the closing “]>”.
Perform the conversion with the db4-upgrade.xsl stylesheet.
Open the new document using your favorite editing tool. Replace all occurrences of the unique string you used to save the entity references with the corresponding entity references.
Paste the document type declaration that you saved onto the top of your new document.
Remove the external identifier (the PUBLIC and/or SYSTEM keywords) from the document type declaration. A document that begins with:

is perfectly well-formed. If you don't remove the references to the DTD, then your parser will likely try to validate against DocBook V4.0 and that's not going to work. Alternatively, you could refer to the DocBook V5.0 DTD.
